How to test your code? That's really a hard question. Usually there are dedicated testers who can help in that by writing test scenarios and apply them. As a developer you need to apply basic testing (testing your code from the end UI), and automated testing. Automated tests varies from project to another; they can be any combination of unit tests, UI tests, and functional tests.

I highly recommend this book (http://www.amazon.com/The-Art-Unit-Testing-Examples/dp/1933988274)to learn how to write good unit tests. I don't have same recommendation for UI or functional testing books.

IMO, I prefer to write as minimum documentation as you can. Your code should be clear enough without much documentation. You can just write documents for the high level design and of course UML is perfect for that.

Of course this does not apply if you're writing tools or APIs to be used by other developers.

Regarding your question about architecture , there is no simple answer. Learning how to design good software can be accomplished by experience and by reading about that science. Experience is not enough. Of course some people has natural talent in software design but without experience or science it is useless.
